column1: Will formal negotiations between Russia and the United States on an extension, modification, or replacement for the New START treaty begin before 1 October 2020?
column6: ['Foreign Policy', 'Security and Conflict']
https://www.rferl.org/a/talks-to-salvage-last-major-nuclear-treaty-between-u-s-russia-to-begin-in-vienna/30683705.html
(no change) Hard to think this does not meet the criteria (but would I ever question GJO?):

It does not matter if formal negotiations regarding a new "START" ""Treaty"" to be extended, modified or replaced between Russia or the USA begin before 1 October 2020. Russia will still defame, disregard, become disloyal and ultimately deceive the USA. The USA and Russia cannot work together. They are both superpowers, however one is vastly more advanced than the other. One president innovated his country into the future and one kept his country in the past. I see a dark future if this treaty takes place.
I know I am running counter to the crowd, but China’s refusal to participate, and Trump not being central, lead me to believe this is posturing only.
Seems like negotiations are taking place as of today [1, 2].
Looks like they will begin. See links below.

According to the news today "The United States and Russia have agreed to start arms control talks on Monday as the only remaining treaty between the two largest nuclear powers will expire in less than a year."
Just asked for Resolution with these links:

These things happen. Frequently. On the other hand, it's not clear from this story that New START will be among the specific topics for the chatfest. Most likely our folks are waiting for The Tulsa Superspreader to hear from Fox News what he's supposed to let them talk about. Could take a while. As a US taxpayer, I wish they were meeting someplace else--the coffee is pretty expensive in Vienna, and they'll probably need a lot.

Until they issue his instructions, he'll let the few surviving professionals go along with whatever they're doing. Meantime he won't let anything interfere with his re-election terrors. I hate going 50-50 on anything, but needs must.

But at the end of May the President gave notice that he was withdrawing from the Open Skies Treaty and made accusations against Russia. An opening gambit in an attempt to negotiate? Remember he has attacked other leaders before trying to negotiate, kind of a “mine’s bigger move.”

Although not extending the treaty gives Trump a chance to show another Obama era treaty he “canceled”, I think the ceremonious aspect of photo-op opportunity to appear on a grand global stage with Putin as a world leader to announce extension may be too much for Trump to pass on in the election year. Although, if extended, very likely that Trump puts a spin on it to the effect that it is a MUCH improved version of the treaty signed during the Obama era.
I'm backing down a bit from 100%. There are dozens of reasons why this SHOULD happen. But still I wonder...

I don’t have numbers and I cannot link an article but based on this administration’s lack of seasoned professional foreign policy service members and the Executive office unwilling to backdown from ill conceived and ill informed decisions, I do not see that happening. There is a greater chance that Trump will nuke a small country out of election desperation and paranoia because no one seems to be willing to stand up to this little boy bully.
Just not the right time to negotiations with Russia.

Neither Trump nor Putin will believe they have anything to gain by commencing negotiations to limit weapons in any form. Both are strongeman type personalties, and both would consider such negotiations to be a display of weakness. Both are currently under pressure because of mishandling their respective responses to the coronavirus; neither will do anything that smacks to them of weakness.

Since Administration wants replacement and not extension the formal negotiations might not start by October. A delay is happening because Billingslea’s Congressional confirmation is being held-up until Trump explains all the IG firings. Still after reading tweets by some Administration officials it appears talks will take place. It is also conceivable an extension will happen. Depends on how hard core Trump is about his agenda having China participate. All the talk about returning to nuke tests, arms race might just be posturing. Raising some on other side of 50. Tough one. Note again to followers: I am taking way too many questions to do Superforecaster level work (made it twice). Do your own research.

My prediction remains at 35% for this week, despite The United States and Russias recent intercommunications. On the 26th of May, United States Press Secretary Kayleigh Mcenany held a briefing regarding the recent riots and protests circulating the U.S. She mentioned a brief call that occurred between President Trump and the Grey Cardinal President Putin earlier that day that piqued my interested. I remained vigilant in observing the news for an update on the conversation. On June 1st, news sources confirmed that that a White House released a statement saying the conversation topics included “the latest efforts to defeat the coronavirus pandemic and reopen global economies” and “progress toward convening the G7.” Considering the totality of events, from the pandemic in Russia and the protests in the U.S., to the restructuring of the political structure in Russia leads me to believe that there is a 35% chance that a renewal START treaty by October 1st 2020. (Especially considering the expiration date is in February and the START treaty historically has an average statistic of being renewed in December). My highest percentage leads to the START treaty being renewed by the end of the year, as opposed to some time next year, as this issue is not as prevelant as others to the international community at this time.

@Wildwood2000 research makes a compelling case so I'm moving it up. I still think that Trump could throw a spanner in the works, his current public sentiment is frosty, but it seems like there is serious movement.

Though I think the chances of at least signing an extension are quite high (Robert O'Brien has said negotiations are going to happen) I'm not sure about the deadline. The fact that nothing has happened so far implies that Trump is going to draw this one out for as long as possible. There is also the added safety net of the Russians saying they will sign it (Which should make the process of extension simpler) and so Trump can cut it fine. It's also another thing that can be used against China which he might want to save.

Uh we wanted tactical weapons to be part of the negotiations. How can we even start to negotiate? “Russia make a new nuclear START: for the first time Russia 2 June has presented a Nuclear Deterrent Policy doctrine, stating nuclear weapons can be used in response to a conventional strike. This, in the run-up to new START treaty negotiations”, “ In a call with members of his Security Council over the weekend, Putin warned that the New START treaty is bound to expire, but "the negotiations on that crucial issue, important not just for us but for the entire world, have failed to start”. NUT June 2.
Oh crowd is at 25%. I see the forecasters who usually do well are on the other side of 50. I guess I am moving closer to the crowd on this one. Will keep searching for more info.

This one is hard. The word ‘formal’ denotes some serious negotiation but the position of the US Administration means they are not even close in starting positions with Russia. Trump has a history of walking away hoping that will result in later leverage. They could conceivably meet on an informal basis to see if there is enough agreement to start formal negotiations. When Obama set-up New Start there were informal talks before they got into formal negotiations with details and working teams. https://sldinfo.com/2020/06/new-appointee-delineates-trumps-nuclear-arms-control-vision/ https://www.defenseone.com/technology/2020/05/trump-administrations-aggressive-approach-arms-negotiatons-could-backfire/165334/ I am going to go slightly below 50% contrary to the crowd.

What is the difference between "formal negotiations" and defense ministers of the relevant countries seriously talking about it? Aren´t they negotiating, when they talk about it from different perspectives? Do they each have to hold up a sign "just negotiating" while talking? Still sure, that sometime before 1 October something will happen to satisfy GJO.
Probably too exuberant. Lowering.
Going down 10% because of an article on the topic by two Russian subject-matter experts.
On reflection, statements to the news do push me up above 50%

Great read: "For more than a year, Mr. Trump has said he would not renew the New START treaty, negotiated by Mr. Obama in 2010, unless China also joined. Beijing has rejected the idea. And it is unclear how that might work even if China agreed to enter the treaty. With 1,550 deployed nuclear weapons each, the United States and Russia would never be willing to reduce their arsenals to the 300 or so held by China. And allowing China to build up to American and Russian levels seems to defeat the purpose of arms control...In a briefing for reporters Thursday afternoon, Mr. Billingslea said that he and his Russian counterparts had agreed to meet on the future of the New START treaty, and that the ***United States would insist that any negotiations include the Chinese.*** He said he was confident the Chinese would participate." https://www.nytimes.com/2020/05/21/us/politics/trump-open-skies-treaty-arms-control.html

The current American administration is facing harsh criticism for its handling of the COVID019 pandemic. While nuclear proliferation is a serious long-term threat, the US executive branch is more focussed on short-term political goals given the election in November. The current administration's reaction to the pandemic involves unilateral action, a non-compromising mindset, and image management. The same attitude applied towards NP will likely mean that there will be no formal negotiations starting before Oct 1 2020.
(no change) I guessed correctly. An extension does not need to be ratified in either the US or Russia:
Down 10%. Nice US State Dept. Wouldn't want anything to happen to it.
Baseline: when in the duration do these kind of treaties normally extend? Within a year is average which would be February 2020. --> 95%

Of the past 7 US-Russia Nuclear Arms treaties, roughly 3/7 were at least renegotiated. Using 43% as a starting point, Russia has shown signs of wanting to renew/engage. The Trump admin, however, has not shown serious signs of this, opting to want a trilateral agreement with China (which is even more complicated by US-China relations in the time of COVID). The US election in November adds further uncertainty, though Trump may start negotiations as a distraction. Trump may also not renew the treaty to help the defense industry (if nuclear proliferation does that? I'm not sure) or as a strongman tool in the election (and trashing the Obama admin as well). I renew down to 20% due to the points against renewal.

This is my guess for an extension. At this current moment in time, I do not believe that there will be a replacement or modification on Russia's part because of President Vladimir Putin's announcement to conduct structural changes in the political structure. According to the Arms Control Fact Sheet on the Strategic Nuclear Arms Control Agreements between Russia and the United States, the expiration date of the current START is February 5, 2021. While these statistics also show that these agreements are generally renewed one year prior to the expiration date, as of this month, COVID19 is increasing in Russia. This means that Russia will experience the side-affects of the virus later than us. Furthermore, the United States President should be tentative about traveling and conducting meetings considering what is happening within the White House at this current moment in time. That being said, the capabilities of telecommunication convince me they can achieve this date. I believe that there is a 30% change that the extension could occur by December. Since Russia is planning on conducting structural changes in their political system, which I believe has an ambitious date of mid-next year, I have the up-most confidence it will occur within 2020.

Meyer, H. (2020). Russia says US shows no readiness to extend key nuclear pact. Bloomberg. May 14, 2020. Retrieved from https://www.detroitnews.com/story/news/nation/2020/05/14/russia-says-us-shows-readiness-extend-key-nuclear-pact/111711722/

There are 3 positions - allow it to expire, renew it for 5 more years and start a New START treaty. With the third ruled out, the first two are possible. As of April 2020, Russia has made an offer to extend. It is with US to accept. The position of US is to include China in the treaty, include more systems for compliance. In an election year, the current administration may not allow to expire to show leadership before the allies that the arms proliferation is under control. Further, there may be an opinion that the pandemic has cast serious concerns about the leadership abilities and therefore, it will be in the interests of the administration to accept the Russian offer.

"The chief negotiator of the New START treaty fears the nuclear arms control deal with Russia could end up 'simply going away' as attention is diverted to handling the novel coronavirus pandemic...Former Under Secretary of State for Arms Control Rose Gottemoeller told Newsweek that she was 'concerned' about the deal lapsing if it is not paid more attention before it expires early next year...Gottemoeller said: 'The attention span of course must be focused on the pandemic. But I am concerned about New START simply going away without the requisite attention to the role it plays in national security for the United States and for our allies in Europe as well.'" https://www.newsweek.com/nuclear-weapons-treaty-negotiator-new-start-could-end-coronavirus-pandemic-1502337
Reducing from 55%, large reduction to adjust for a prolonged stay at prior optimistic levels. Possible, but not likely.

The upcoming presidential election lowers the chance of this happening. However, Depending on how other events play out over the summer of 2020, President Trump may attempt negotiations in late summer or fall in an effort to boost his approval rating before the election.

Slight decrease on crowd forecast. Current global uncertainty, upcoming presidential election adding to this. The possibility for the current deal to be extended seems a viable option as the START treaty becomes a less pressing matter on the global agenda. Further, anticipating a divergence in US China relations makes the likelihood of tri-lateral policy agreement lower.

Since the lapse of START and it’s recast in 2011, the former administration on multiple occasions pressed that the Chinese be included in any future talks. The Trump administration has said likewise and a recent RFL report quoted a US official saying that both Moscow and Washington support the notion. The Chinese on the other hand haven’t publicly announced any intention to participate in any arms control treaty with either the US or Russia. Given that China’s nuclear arsenal is a minuscule fraction of the US-Russian stockpiles at stake, insistence that the Chinese must participate isn’t exactly a practicality. Moreover, the recent and abrupt ending of the IRNF treaty last year has stoltified an already stale non-proliferation regime. Additionally and less remembered is the development of hypersonic weaponry by Russia which greatly disrupts previously held doctrines of strategic arms control.

Fairlamb, J. (2020). Time to restart nuclear arms negotiations with Russia. The Hill. Opinion. May 3. 2020. Retrieved from https://thehill.com/opinion/international/494960-time-to-restart-nuclear-arms-negotiations-with-russia

"However, we have yet to get a response. Trump administration representatives keep claiming that “there is still time” since the extension of the treaty in their view can be formalized in a matter of days. These statements are made despite our repeated clarifications that New START’s extension is not a “mere technicality,” but a rather extensive process that requires the Russian side to undertake a series of domestic legislative procedures. I would like to reiterate that as past similar review processes show, it may take several months to complete the New START extension."

Very tough one: On the one hand the Russians are keen to do it and Trump could probably use the highlights. Maybe official negotiations are possible before October 1st since there's the idea to have UN Security Counsel Session in September On the other hand Trump stated multiple times he wants China in the deal, he has not brokered any arms control deals as President and the fact that Russia is keen will make Trump push hard for concessions. Also, the domestic agendas are fragile in both Russia and the US with COVID and internal dissatisfaction with the presidents.

"U.S. Secretary of State Mike Pompeo told his Russian counterpart...that any future arms control talks must focus on an American proposal for a new arms control accord that includes Russia and China, the State Department said...U.S. administration officials argue that China must be brought into any new arms control pact because of the growing threat they say is posed by its nuclear arsenal, which is undergoing a modernization program...Arms control experts, however, have described Trump’s proposal to include China in a new treaty as a “poison pill” strategy to kill New START and end restraints on U.S. nuclear arms deployments." https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-russia-armscontrol/pompeo-tells-russias-lavrov-any-new-arms-control-talks-must-include-china-idUSKBN21Z2P9
Both sides could view an extension to the this agreement as a easy win. As with all things being predicted in our CoVid world it would be hard to see either side spending time on this topic.

This is very unlikely based on the current administrations of both countries. But, if both of them are looking for a quick win; perhaps before the Nov election in the US and if Putin is looking to gain favor with some groups in Russia, this could happen.

Putin has explicitly stated that he is ready to extend the New START Deal. Trump might use it as a card to woo Democratic voter base The current deal expires next February, so that is also a factor that would contribute to hastening decisions regarding issues as serious as Nuclear Arsenal

The Current US presidency: there is a lot to be said about the toxicity of international relations under the current US presidency which leads to a low chance that there will be a discussion of the New Start before this date; however, this does not mean that there is a need to further this discussion in 2020. This situation can be described by a quote from the Economist “Both sides have reservations that need to be dealt with before an extension can be agreed—but nothing that cannot be overcome given sufficient political will. Serious negotiations need to start soon to get a deal done in time.” (1) It seems likely that there would be serious steps to make these negotiations happen if they would benefit Mr. Trump. In the comment noted by O’Brien on CNN, there is brought to the table the importance of nations, not just the US and Russia- with this in mind, there may be pressures for both parties to move forward in starting the negotiations now rather than later. The sources provided show the importance of negotiations as 2021 will bring the end of the old treaty and the need for the New Start treaty will be crucial (2). Finally, with either pressure in full swings such as the COVID-19 pandemic and US 2020 election underway, I think there is reason to believe negotiations will be pushed back. Though, these same factors make me think that as many things seem out of control at times, the beginning of these negotiations (that may take quite some time) will be even more neccessary going into the Fall of 2020. Based on the factors discussed, I forecast a 45% chance that they will start before October 1, 2020. This forecast also accounts for the fact that negotiations may start in the time after Oct 1 and before Jan 1 2021.

Overall, it seems unlikely that the treaty would be extended. While proponents claim that it has strengthened international security and strategic stability, and Russia has indicated its willingness in the past to discuss extensions, President Trump is no stranger to flouting established international norms and is a vocal critic of nearly all of Obama’s policies. He has expressed the desire to renegotiate a better deal for the US with respect to US-Russian arms agreements, and has also indicated that he wants to involve China in the next treaty iteration: this would serve no purpose for China as it has a far smaller nuclear arsenal than either of the other two countries and thus would clearly get the short end of the stick in any deal involving the three. Lastly, the coronavirus pandemic means that, for the moment, the treaty is not the highest priority for the Trump administration; this may change if the pandemic comes under control, but for the moment Trump’s attention is surely divided.

Several questions: 1) are they still interested in what START is about? Answer: of course they are. It´s been active for more than 9 years now, and each side could have withdrawn the whole time. From the treaty: "Duration and Withdrawal (Article XIV) The treaty’s duration is ten years from entry into force (Feb. 2021) unless it is superseded by a subsequent agreement and can be extended for an additional five years, until 2026. As in START I, each party can withdraw if it decides for itself that “extraordinary events related to the subject matter of this treaty have jeopardized its supreme interests.” The treaty would terminate three months from a notice of withdrawal". 99% yes 2) Looking at the answer to question 1: has anything significant changed, that would make NOT extending reasonable ? Answer: They didn´t even withdraw because of Ukraine etc.. Trump has been in power long enough not to consider him a risk on this one, Virusses don´t affect nuclear arms.
